HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 19, 1926.

FRESHMEN ANNOUNCE
BANQUET COMMITTEE
Running counter to all tradition and assuming a bold
front the freshman class, last
Wednesday announced its
banquet committee. President Ness told the class at
its meeting that this committee, consisting of J. Waters,
Chairman, J. Willison, W.
Banks, W. Welsh and G.
Hill, would have complete
charge of the freshman activities during banquet week,
both in attack and defense.
The sophomores and the majority of the freshman themselves are at a loss to explain
this unusual action. Not
only is it unusual for a banquet committee to •be made
public by the first two classes
but it is very early in the
year for these committees to
be appointed.

TRUSTEES NOT DECIDED ON
NEW PLAN, EDMUNDS ASSERTS

HOPKINS MEETS DELAWARE
IN K. OF C. POOL
TONIGHT
Northerners' Strength Unknown, But
Blue Jays Expect Victory;
McCleary Out

After nearly three weeks of
hard practice the Hopkins swimmers are fully prepared to enter
their second competition tonight.
Delaware, an unknown quantity
to local authorities on sports, is
said to have several fast men,
especially in-the fifty and hundred
yard dashes. However, the Black
and Blue team does not expect to
come out on the small end again.
All the men are in good shape
but 'McCleary, who is suffering
from a boil. Muir and Stevens
will probably handle the backstroke in case McCleary in unable
to swim. Muir took second place
in a recent open meet at the K. of

C., and Stevens had experience on
the 1924 team. Hopkins is weakest at present in this, the 440, and
fancy diving events. Davis - is
rounding into much better shape
in the quarter-mile grind. Stone
and Hemmeter will dive, since
Mengers will be unable to be present.
Freshmen Best

The back-bone of the Delaware
squad, from all reports, appears
to consist of three freshmen, one
of which is president of his class.
These men are as follows:
-Happy" Howell, a former AllVirginian backstroke champion,
who hails from Randolph-Macon;
Edgar Reese, president of the
freshman class, who made second
place in the Columbia InterScholastic meet last year; and another: freshman, Nobis, who has
done well in the breaststroke.
As the back stroke is the Blue
Jays' weakest spot, Howell appears to be Delaware's greatest
threat.
Recent time trials showed great
improvement in the squad. Captain Welsh is almost certain of
two first places, while Bailey,
who has been pushing Welsh
lately, is sure :to place in the
hundred. The relay team also
has improved and will give Delaware trouble.
Lower' Records

It is an interesting fact that the
times made by the Jays in the
Rutgers meet are, in most cases,
below those which brought victory
to Columbia in her recent meet
with Army.
The reliable Blue Jay Orchestra
will again furnish the syncopation
at the dance, which has become
a regular accompaniment to every
swimming meet: Two 'weeks ago
there was a very good attendance
despite the fact that several large
parties were scheduled for. the
same night. It is hoped by the
manager and all the team that
these dances will continue to be
popular, so that the team may be
as nearly as possible selfsupporting.

TINKLING GALOSHES RESOUND ON

Synonymous with every snowfall is the further growth of the
galosh fad. The noisy clattr and
sucking of the galoshes has taken
its place with the other campus

When it's a rainy
night—and with three crafty
bridge players your luck
is running wild
have a Camel!
WHEN the dark skies are
pouring rain outside.
And fickle fate deals you
hands at bridge that you
play with consummate
skill—have a Camel!
For Camel is the silent
partner that helps every
deserving player win his
game. Camels never hurt
or tire the taste, never
leave a trace of cigaretty
after-taste. Regardless of
the gold you spend,
you'll never get choicer
tobaccos than those
rolled into Camels.
So this evening as you
ply your unerring skill,
evoke then the mellowest fragrance that ever
came from a cigarette.
Have a Camel!

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 19, 1926.

First we stated the case,
then we argued it/
Now We Make A Request
(Copies Upon Application)

(Copies Upon Application)

UR viewpoint in presenting the case may not have been
acceptable to you.
Our arguments may not have convinced you that what
we contend for is logical, sound and desirable.
If these are the facts, then the fault is ours in lacking the power
and ability to present clearly and convincingly what in days to
come will prove absolutely right.
BUT WILL YOU GRANT US A FAVOR?
Will you turn to your calendar and mark a
ring around February 22nd?
Tell your wife, sweetheart, secretary or office boy
that you have made a date with yourself on that
day to be nothing but a Hopkins Man from A. M.
to midnight.
That you are going to the Commemoration Exercises at Peabody Institute at 11 o'clock.
(Be sure and reserve your seat in advance.)
That at that meeting you are going to hear Dr.
Michael I. Pupin, chairman of the New York
Alumni Half-Century Fund.
—the same eminent scientist who four
years ago wrote "No rich man in the
United States should die without leaving
money to Hopkins" but who today says
"No rich man in the United States should
wait to die before giving money to Hopkins."
That you are going to dedicate the afternoon to
Hopkins in thought, word and deed.
That you are going to attend the Hopkins Rally
at night.
That you are going to hold forth with your fellow
Alumni and side-kicks of other days in heart to
heart discussion of Hopkins' future.
That if you find a Hopkins man oppostd to the
new order of things involving decreased undergraduate activity and more highly developed
graduate and research work, that you will argue
the question out to a conclusion.
Signed

That you will point out to him the prestige, influence and accomplishments of the medical school
through the pursuance of just such a policy and
the necessity of putting all other departments in
the University on a like plane.
That you will meet the argument of the Hopkins
man who contends that the new era will neglect
the local needs of the Baltimore boy, selling him the
idea of solving the great outstanding problem first
and incidental problems later.
That you will strengthen your conviction in the
soundness of your judgment by recalling that some
of the most distinguished J. H. U. Alumni have
set forth objection after objection to the new plan
until talking to our leaders: Goodnow, Welch,
Willard, Ames et al—and have then become
among the warmest of the proposed new Program's
supporters.
PLEASE REMEMBER—
This is a strictly unofficial communication, as have
been the others which have preceded.
No one in authority at the University is directly
or indirectly responsible for these arguments or
appeals.
Just ourselves and a few friends who are fully sold
on the desirability of having all Hopkins men working toward a common end have accorded ourselves
the personal privilege of addressing you.
There's Big Work to do—
so let's be up and doing.
As Hopkins men to a Hopkins man, just make a
note of that date with yourself on February 22nd.
We'll see you then—Thank you!

Wm. D. LILLY, J. H. U., Class '96

SYDNEY M. CONE, M. D., J. H. U.. A. B.'90

DUSHANE PENNIMAN, J. H. U., A. B.'14

BANQUET COMMITTEE
Running counter to all tradition and assuming a bold
front the freshman class, last
Wednesday announced its
banquet committee. President Ness told the class at
its meeting that this committee, consisting of J. Waters,
Chairman, J. Willison, W.
Banks, W. Welsh and G.
Hill, would have complete
charge of the freshman activities during banquet week,
both in attack and defense.
The sophomores and the majority of the freshman themselves are at a loss to explain
this unusual action. Not
only is it unusual for a banquet committee to •be made
public by the first two classes
but it is very early in the
year for these committees to
be appointed.

HOPKINS MEETS DELAWARE
IN K. OF C. POOL
TONIGHT
Northerners' Strength Unknown, But
Blue Jays Expect Victory;
McCleary Out

After nearly three weeks of
hard practice the Hopkins swimmers are fully prepared to enter
their second competition tonight.
Delaware, an unknown quantity
to local authorities on sports, is
said to have several fast men,
especially in-the fifty and hundred
yard dashes. However, the Black
and Blue team does not expect to
come out on the small end again.
All the men are in good shape
but 'McCleary, who is suffering
from a boil. Muir and Stevens
will probably handle the backstroke in case McCleary in unable
to swim. Muir took second place
in a recent open meet at the K. of

C., and Stevens had experience on
the 1924 team. Hopkins is weakest at present in this, the 440, and
fancy diving events. Davis - is
rounding into much better shape
in the quarter-mile grind. Stone
and Hemmeter will dive, since
Mengers will be unable to be present.
Freshmen Best

The back-bone of the Delaware
squad, from all reports, appears
to consist of three freshmen, one
of which is president of his class.
These men are as follows:
-Happy" Howell, a former AllVirginian backstroke champion,
who hails from Randolph-Macon;
Edgar Reese, president of the
freshman class, who made second
place in the Columbia InterScholastic meet last year; and another: freshman, Nobis, who has
done well in the breaststroke.
As the back stroke is the Blue
Jays' weakest spot, Howell appears to be Delaware's greatest
threat.
Recent time trials showed great
improvement in the squad. Captain Welsh is almost certain of
two first places, while Bailey,
who has been pushing Welsh
lately, is sure :to place in the
hundred. The relay team also
has improved and will give Delaware trouble.
Lower' Records

It is an interesting fact that the
times made by the Jays in the
Rutgers meet are, in most cases,
below those which brought victory
to Columbia in her recent meet
with Army.
The reliable Blue Jay Orchestra
will again furnish the syncopation
at the dance, which has become
a regular accompaniment to every
swimming meet: Two 'weeks ago
there was a very good attendance
despite the fact that several large
parties were scheduled for. the
same night. It is hoped by the
manager and all the team that
these dances will continue to be
popular, so that the team may be
as nearly as possible selfsupporting.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 19, 1926.

First we stated the case,
then we argued it/
Now We Make A Request
(Copies Upon Application)

(Copies Upon Application)

UR viewpoint in presenting the case may not have been
acceptable to you.
Our arguments may not have convinced you that what
we contend for is logical, sound and desirable.
If these are the facts, then the fault is ours in lacking the power
and ability to present clearly and convincingly what in days to
come will prove absolutely right.
BUT WILL YOU GRANT US A FAVOR?
Will you turn to your calendar and mark a
ring around February 22nd?
Tell your wife, sweetheart, secretary or office boy
that you have made a date with yourself on that
day to be nothing but a Hopkins Man from A. M.
to midnight.
That you are going to the Commemoration Exercises at Peabody Institute at 11 o'clock.
(Be sure and reserve your seat in advance.)
That at that meeting you are going to hear Dr.
Michael I. Pupin, chairman of the New York
Alumni Half-Century Fund.
—the same eminent scientist who four
years ago wrote "No rich man in the
United States should die without leaving
money to Hopkins" but who today says
"No rich man in the United States should
wait to die before giving money to Hopkins."
That you are going to dedicate the afternoon to
Hopkins in thought, word and deed.
That you are going to attend the Hopkins Rally
at night.
That you are going to hold forth with your fellow
Alumni and side-kicks of other days in heart to
heart discussion of Hopkins' future.
That if you find a Hopkins man oppostd to the
new order of things involving decreased undergraduate activity and more highly developed
graduate and research work, that you will argue
the question out to a conclusion.
Signed

That you will point out to him the prestige, influence and accomplishments of the medical school
through the pursuance of just such a policy and
the necessity of putting all other departments in
the University on a like plane.
That you will meet the argument of the Hopkins
man who contends that the new era will neglect
the local needs of the Baltimore boy, selling him the
idea of solving the great outstanding problem first
and incidental problems later.
That you will strengthen your conviction in the
soundness of your judgment by recalling that some
of the most distinguished J. H. U. Alumni have
set forth objection after objection to the new plan
until talking to our leaders: Goodnow, Welch,
Willard, Ames et al—and have then become
among the warmest of the proposed new Program's
supporters.
PLEASE REMEMBER—
This is a strictly unofficial communication, as have
been the others which have preceded.
No one in authority at the University is directly
or indirectly responsible for these arguments or
appeals.
Just ourselves and a few friends who are fully sold
on the desirability of having all Hopkins men working toward a common end have accorded ourselves
the personal privilege of addressing you.
There's Big Work to do—
so let's be up and doing.
As Hopkins men to a Hopkins man, just make a
note of that date with yourself on February 22nd.
We'll see you then—Thank you!

Wm. D. LILLY, J. H. U., Class '96

SYDNEY M. CONE, M. D., J. H. U.. A. B.'90

DUSHANE PENNIMAN, J. H. U., A. B.'14
